column2: That boy's whole life was changed; sober and sad he was ever after.
column3: That boy's whole life was changed; sober and sad he was ever after.

column2: He is now a gray haired old man, with one sorrow over his one act of disobedience, one wrong word embittering all his life--with those words ever ringing in his ears, "Mother, I don't love you now."
column3: He is now a gray haired old man, with one sorrow over his one act of disobedience, one wrong word embittering all his life-with those words ever ringing in his ears, "Mother, I don't love you now."

column2: Will the little ones who read this remember, if they disobey their mother, if they are cross and naughty, they say every single time they do so, to a tender mother's heart, by their actions if not in the words of Henry, the very same thing, "I don't love you now, Mother."
column3: Will the little ones who read this remember, if they disobey their mother, if they are cross and naughty, they say every single time they do so, to a tender mother's heart, by their actions if not in the words of Henry, the very same thing, "I don't love you now, Mother."

column2: LITTLE MOTHER
column3: LITTLE MOTHER

column2: She was a clear-eyed, fresh-cheeked little maiden, living on the banks of the great Mississippi, the oldest of four children, and mother's "little woman" always.
column3: She was a clear eyed, fresh cheeked little maiden, living on the banks of the great Mississippi, the oldest of four children, and mother's "little woman" always.

column2: They called her so because of her quiet, matronly care of the younger Mayfields--that was the father's name.
column3: They called her so because of her quiet, matronly care of the younger Mayfields-that was the father's name.

column2: Her own name was the beautiful one of Elizabeth, but they shortened it to Bess.
column3: Her own name was the beautiful one of Elizabeth, but they shortened it to Bess.

column2: She was thirteen when one day Mr. Mayfield and his wife were called to the nearest town, six miles away.
column3: She was thirteen when one day mr Mayfield and his wife were called to the nearest town, six miles away.

column2: Be mother's little woman, dear, said Mrs. Mayfield as she kissed the rosy face.
column3: Be mother's little woman, dear, said mrs Mayfield as she kissed the rosy face.

column2: Her husband added: "I leave the children in your care, Bess; be a little mother to them."
column3: Her husband added: "I leave the children in your care, Bess; be a little mother to them."

column2: Bess waved her old sun-bonnet vigorously, and held up the baby Rose, that she might watch them to the last.
column3: Bess waved her old sun bonnet vigorously, and held up the baby Rose, that she might watch them to the last.

column2: Old Daddy Jim and Mammy had been detailed by Mr. Mayfield to keep an unsuspected watch on the little nestlings, and were to sleep at the house.
column3: Old Daddy Jim and Mammy had been detailed by mr Mayfield to keep an unsuspected watch on the little nestlings, and were to sleep at the house.

column2: Thus two days went by, when Daddy Jim and Mammy begged to be allowed to go to the quarters where the Negroes lived, to see their daughter, "Jennie, who was pow'ful bad wid the toothache." They declared they would be back by evening, so Bess was willing.
column3: Thus two days went by, when Daddy Jim and Mammy begged to be allowed to go to the quarters where the Negroes lived, to see their daughter, "Jennie, who was pow'ful bad wid the toothache." They declared they would be back by evening, so Bess was willing.

column2: She put the little girls to bed and persuaded Rob to go; then seated herself by the table with her mother's work-basket, in quaint imitation of Mrs. Mayfield's industry in the evening time.
column3: She put the little girls to bed and persuaded Rob to go; then seated herself by the table with her mother's work basket, in quaint imitation of mrs Mayfield's industry in the evening time.

column2: But what was this?
column3: But what was this?

column2: Her feet touched something cold!
column3: Her feet touched something cold!

column2: She bent down and felt around with her hand.
column3: She bent down and felt around with her hand.

column2: A pool of water was spreading over the floor.
column3: A pool of water was spreading over the floor.

column2: She knew what it was; the Mississippi had broken through the levee.
column3: She knew what it was; the Mississippi had broken through the levee.

column2: What should she do?
column3: What should she do?

column2: Mammy's stories of how homes had been washed away and broken in pieces were in her mind.
column3: Mammy's stories of how homes had been washed away and broken in pieces were in her mind.

column2: Oh, if I had a boat! she exclaimed.
column3: Oh, if I had a boat! she exclaimed.

column2: But there isn't anything of the sort on the place. She ran wildly out to look for Mammy; and stumbled over something sitting near the edge of the porch. A sudden inspiration took her.
column3: But there isn't anything of the sort on the place. She ran wildly out to look for Mammy; and stumbled over something sitting near the edge of the porch. A sudden inspiration took her.

column2: Here was her boat! a very large, old-fashioned, oblong tub.
column3: Here was her boat! a very large, old-fashioned, oblong tub.

column2: The water was now several inches deep on the porch and she contrived to half-float, half-row the tub into the room.
column3: The water was now several inches deep on the porch and she contrived to half float, half row the tub into the room.

column2: Without frightening the children she got them dressed in the warmest clothes they had.
column3: Without frightening the children she got them dressed in the warmest clothes they had.

column2: She lined the oblong tub with a blanket, and made ready bread and cold meat left from supper.
column3: She lined the oblong tub with a blanket, and made ready bread and cold meat left from supper.

column2: With Rob's assistance she dragged the tub upstairs.
column3: With Rob's assistance she dragged the tub upstairs.

column2: There was a single large window in the room, and they set the tub directly by it, so that when the water rose the tub would float out.
column3: There was a single large window in the room, and they set the tub directly by it, so that when the water rose the tub would float out.

column2: There was no way for the children to reach the roof, which was a very steep, inclined one.
column3: There was no way for the children to reach the roof, which was a very steep, inclined one.

column2: It did not seem long before the water had very nearly risen to the top of the stairs leading from below.
column3: It did not seem long before the water had very nearly risen to the top of the stairs leading from below.

column2: Bess flung the window open, and made Rob get into their novel boat; then she lifted in Kate, and finally baby Rose, who began to cry, was given into Rob's arms, and now the little mother, taking the basket of food, made ready to enter, too; but, lo! there was no room for her with safety to the rest.
column3: Bess flung the window open, and made Rob get into their novel boat; then she lifted in Kate, and finally baby Rose, who began to cry, was given into Rob's arms, and now the little mother, taking the basket of food, made ready to enter, too; but, lo! there was no room for her with safety to the rest.

column2: Bess paused a moment, drew a long breath, and kissed the children quietly.
column3: Bess paused a moment, drew a long breath, and kissed the children quietly.

column2: She explained to Rob that he must guard the basket, and that they must sit still.
column3: She explained to Rob that he must guard the basket, and that they must sit still.

column2: Goodbye, dears.	Goodbye, dears.
column3: true

column2: Say a prayer for sister, Rob.
column3: Say a prayer for sister, Rob.

column2: If you ever see father and mother, tell them I took care of you." Then the water seized the insecure vessel, and out into the dark night it floated.
column3: If you ever see father and mother, tell them I took care of you." Then the water seized the insecure vessel, and out into the dark night it floated.

column2: The next day Mr. Mayfield, who, with his neighbors, scoured the broad lake of eddying water that represented the Mississippi, discovered the tub lodged in the branches of a sycamore with the children weeping and chilled, but safe.
column3: The next day mr Mayfield, who, with his neighbors, scoured the broad lake of eddying water that represented the Mississippi, discovered the tub lodged in the branches of a sycamore with the children weeping and chilled, but safe.

column2: And Bess?
column3: And Bess?

column2: Ah, where was Bess, the "little mother," who in that brief moment resigned herself to death?
column3: Ah, where was Bess, the "little mother," who in that brief moment resigned herself to death?

column2: They found her later, floating on the water with her brave childish face turned to the sky; and as strong arms lifted her into the boat, the tears from every eye paid worthy tribute to the "little mother."
column3: They found her later, floating on the water with her brave childish face turned to the sky; and as strong arms lifted her into the boat, the tears from every eye paid worthy tribute to the "little mother."

column2: ROBBIE GOODMAN'S PRAYER
column3: ROBBIE GOODMAN'S PRAYER

column2: What can be the matter with Walter, thought Mama Ellis as she sat sewing in her pleasant sitting-room.
column3: What can be the matter with Walter, thought Mama Ellis as she sat sewing in her pleasant sitting room.

column2: He came in so very quietly, closed the door gently and I think I even heard him go to the closet to hang up his books.	He came in so very quietly, closed the door gently and I think I even heard him go to the closet to hang up his books.

column2: Oh! dear.
column3: Oh! dear.

column2: I hope he isn't going to have another attack of 'Grippe,'" and Mrs. Ellis shivered as she glanced out at the snow-covered landscape.
column3: I hope he isn't going to have another attack of 'Grippe,'" and mrs Ellis shivered as she glanced out at the snow covered landscape.

column2: As her eyes turned once more to the warm, luxurious room in which she was seated, the portieres were pushed aside and a little boy of ten years of age entered.
column3: As her eyes turned once more to the warm, luxurious room in which she was seated, the portieres were pushed aside and a little boy of ten years of age entered.

column2: Little Walter was all that remained of four beautiful children, who, only a year ago, romped gaily through the large halls.
column3: Little Walter was all that remained of four beautiful children, who, only a year ago, romped gaily through the large halls.

column2: That dread disease, diphtheria, had stolen the older brother and laughing little sisters in one short week's time, so that now, as the sad anniversary came near to hand, Mrs. Ellis' heart ached for her lost birdlings and yearned more jealously than ever over her remaining little one.
column3: That dread disease, diphtheria, had stolen the older brother and laughing little sisters in one short week's time, so that now, as the sad anniversary came near to hand, mrs Ellis' heart ached for her lost birdlings and yearned more jealously than ever over her remaining little one.

column2: Today his usually merry face was very grave and he looked very thoughtful as he gave his mother her kiss and allowed himself to be drawn upon her lap.
column3: Today his usually merry face was very grave and he looked very thoughtful as he gave his mother her kiss and allowed himself to be drawn upon her lap.

column2: What ails mother's Pet?	What ails mother's Pet?

column2: Is he sick?" she asked anxiously.
column3: Is he sick?" she asked anxiously.

column2: No, Mother dear, I'm not sick, but I feel so sad at heart.	No, Mother dear, I'm not sick, but I feel so sad at heart.
column3: true

column2: You see," he continued in answer to her questioning look, "Robbie Goodman and I always walk together going and coming from school, and I have noticed that he has never worn any overcoat this winter, but you know its been unusually warm and I thought perhaps his mother did not make him wrap up like you did me, but this morning it was so cold and he was just shivering, but he never had on any overcoat--just his mittens and muffler and cap were his wraps.
column3: You see," he continued in answer to her questioning look, "Robbie Goodman and I always walk together going and coming from school, and I have noticed that he has never worn any overcoat this winter, but you know its been unusually warm and I thought perhaps his mother did not make him wrap up like you did me, but this morning it was so cold and he was just shivering, but he never had on any overcoat-just his mittens and muffler and cap were his wraps.

column2: Of course I noticed it, for nearly everyone else was all bundled up; but I didn't say anything as I did not want to be impolite.
column3: Of course I noticed it, for nearly everyone else was all bundled up; but I didn't say anything as I did not want to be impolite.

column2: After awhile he said, 'My, I am so cold,' and I said: 'Where's your overcoat?' Then he told me it was too small and his papa can't buy him any this winter so he is afraid he will have to stop school.
column3: After awhile he said, 'My, I am so cold,' and I said: 'Where's your overcoat?' Then he told me it was too small and his papa can't buy him any this winter so he is afraid he will have to stop school.

column2: His mama says she would cut his papa's up for him, only then he would not have any; and of course he must have one to wear when he goes to the chapel and to see sick people.
column3: His mama says she would cut his papa's up for him, only then he would not have any; and of course he must have one to wear when he goes to the chapel and to see sick people.

column2: Even that one is thin and patched.
column3: Even that one is thin and patched.

column2: He says he and his little sisters have been praying so hard for an overcoat for him and shoes for them, but they did not come at Christmas like they thought they would, and they are real discouraged.
column3: He says he and his little sisters have been praying so hard for an overcoat for him and shoes for them, but they did not come at Christmas like they thought they would, and they are real discouraged.

column2: Tonight, Mother, continued Walter, "he had an awful cold and coughed just like our Harry did last year," and the long pent up tears flowed from the child's eyes.
column3: Tonight, Mother, continued Walter, "he had an awful cold and coughed just like our Harry did last year," and the long pent up tears flowed from the child's eyes.

column2: As mother and son dried their tears, the child looked up with perfect confidence as he said, "The Lord will answer Robbie's prayer, won't he.
column3: As mother and son dried their tears, the child looked up with perfect confidence as he said, "The Lord will answer Robbie's prayer, won't he.

column2: By the way, my dear, remarked Mrs. Ellis as they sat chatting at the tea-table after Walter had retired, "what has become of that preacher Goodman who preached for us once on trial?"
column3: By the way, my dear, remarked mrs Ellis as they sat chatting at the tea table after Walter had retired, "what has become of that preacher Goodman who preached for us once on trial?"

column2: I met him the other day.

column2: He looked very needy.

column2: The man had wonderful talents and might have a rich congregation and improve himself; but he is persistent in his ideas concerning this holiness movement, and of course a large church like ours wants something to attract and interest instead of such egotistical discourses.

column3: Oh, yes, interrupted her husband, "he met me in the hall and poured out the whole story.

column3: The child's nerves were all wrought up, too.

column2: He should not be allowed to worry over such things.

column2: He wants me to give up buying him the fur-trimmed overcoat and get a coat and shoes for Goodman's children, as they were praying so hard for them, but I have enough to do without clothing other people's children.
column3: He wants me to give up buying him the fur trimmed overcoat and get a coat and shoes for Goodman's children, as they were praying so hard for them, but I have enough to do without clothing other people's children.

column2: If Goodman would quit his cranky notions and use his talents for people who could understand him, instead of preaching to those ragamuffins he might now be receiving a magnificent salary and clothing himself and family decently."
column3: If Goodman would quit his cranky notions and use his talents for people who could understand him, instead of preaching to those ragamuffins he might now be receiving a magnificent salary and clothing himself and family decently."

column2: But Paul, said Mrs. Ellis, "Surely you would not have Mr. Goodman sacrifice his convictions simply for money and praise, when you yourself, are convinced that his doctrines are sound?
column3: But Paul, said mrs Ellis, "Surely you would not have mr Goodman sacrifice his convictions simply for money and praise, when you yourself, are convinced that his doctrines are sound?

column2: Besides he must be doing a good work down among the poor classes of the city as it appears the rich don't want him."
column3: Besides he must be doing a good work down among the poor classes of the city as it appears the rich don't want him."

column2: Then let the poor give enough to keep him.

column2: They do give far beyond their means but the Lord calls on such as us to give.	They do give far beyond their means but the Lord calls on such as us to give.

column2: I know it has been an unusually hard year but the Lord has blessed us and He will hold us to an account.
column3: I know it has been an unusually hard year but the Lord has blessed us and He will hold us to an account.

column2: I feel very sad as the anniversary of our darlings' departure draws near and I dread to think of any little ones suffering while we could so easily help them."
column3: I feel very sad as the anniversary of our darlings' departure draws near and I dread to think of any little ones suffering while we could so easily help them."

column2: I don't see how you can feel that we have been so blessed.	I don't see how you can feel that we have been so blessed.

column2: When the house is so quiet and I think of those white graves in the cemetery I confess I feel very bitter."
column3: When the house is so quiet and I think of those white graves in the cemetery I confess I feel very bitter."

column2: Paul, my dear husband, don't feel that way.	Paul, my dear husband, don't feel that way.

column2: Just think of our three treasures in heaven, an added claim to that glorious realm, away from this cold and suffering.
column3: Just think of our three treasures in heaven, an added claim to that glorious realm, away from this cold and suffering.

column2: Remember also that we have one left, to live for, to train.
column3: Remember also that we have one left, to live for, to train.

column2: And, Paul, let us train him for the Master and in such a way that we may never have the feeling that it were better if he, too, had departed when he was pure and innocent.
column3: And, Paul, let us train him for the Master and in such a way that we may never have the feeling that it were better if he, too, had departed when he was pure and innocent.

column2: Let us encourage benevolence and gentleness and if he wishes to go without the fur-trimmed coat, why not do as he asks?" Mrs. Ellis kissed her husband and quietly left the room.
column3: Let us encourage benevolence and gentleness and if he wishes to go without the fur trimmed coat, why not do as he asks?" mrs Ellis kissed her husband and quietly left the room.

column2: Long and late, Paul Ellis sat there and many things, ghosts of the past, rose before him.
column3: Long and late, Paul Ellis sat there and many things, ghosts of the past, rose before him.

column2: As the midnight chimes rang out he knelt and prayed. "Oh, Lord, forgive me.
column3: As the midnight chimes rang out he knelt and prayed. "Oh, Lord, forgive me.

column2: I have gone astray and turned to my own way.
column3: I have gone astray and turned to my own way.

column2: I have been prejudiced.
column3: I have been prejudiced.

column2: It was my influence which turned the tide against Robert Goodman.
column3: It was my influence which turned the tide against Robert Goodman.

column2: Thou knowest.

column2: Now, if Thou wilt only forgive and help me I will walk in the light as Thou sendest it, even consenting to be called a 'holiness crank.'"
